repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - HIV/AIDS and STDs Prevention
            and Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project ratings for the Indonesia
            HIV/AIDS and STDs Prevention and Management Project are as
            follows: Project outcome is unsatisfactory; sustainability
            is unlikely; institutional development impact is negligible;
            Bank performance is unsatisfactory; and Borrower performance
            is unsatisfactory. Despite its failure to achieve
            satisfactory development outcomes, this project offers
            valuable lessons, including confirmation of experience in
            other countries. Specific lessons include: 1) If you amplify
            HIV/AIDS messages in the face of uncertainty, you risk
            undermining those activities that require that you
            continuously nurture political and institutional support. 2)
            If you fail to assess institutional options and
            responsibilities prior to the launch of the project and fail
            to develop local ownership, institutional arrangements
            within the agency leading the AIDS response will become
            unworkable. 3) To develop AIDS-related institutions and
            services requires that engagement with clients for the
            long-term, rather than through a three-year pilot operation.
            4) More donor funds may be available in some environments,
            particularly in the pre-epidemic stages of HIV, than
            recipient countries are able to absorb. This is so in
            particular for direct HIV/AIDS services that are provided
            through nongovernmental organizations. 5) The physical
            proximity of the task manager in the Country Office does not
            necessarily strengthen supervisory support for project implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - HIV/AIDS and STDs Prevention
            and Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the HIV/AIDS and STDs
            Prevention and Management Project was rated as
            unsatisfactory. The project was successful in developing a
            laboratory system to support HIV/AIDS and STD testing and
            surveillance, unfortunately support from the other
            components was negligible. As a result, the project was not
            able to produce a comprehensive model of proved
            effectiveness for the prevention and management of HIV/AIDS
            and STDs. Bank supervision was ineffective in pushing
            attainment of project goals. Key lessons drawn this project
            include: 1) the project was ambitious in its design and
            objectives. Three years was too short a period for achieving
            behavioral change targets, particularly since most
            guidelines, manuals, modules, and information, education,
            and communication materials materials were still to be
            developed during the first years of the project. 2) The
            decision to establish a Project Management Unit (PMU) led by
            a Project Manager who was responsible not just for project
            administration but also for technical matters proved to be
            counter productive. 3) The project was a pilot that had to
            deal with numerous activities in a short time frame,
            involving multiple groups of people, numerous agencies and
            individuals in different locations. 4) The project correctly
            put an nongovernmental organizations capacity building
            component in the project, which was directed particularly at
            smaller nongovernmental organizations with strong ties to
            particular groups of interest.

5082734.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - HIV/AIDS and STDs Prevention
            and Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The HIV/AIDS and Sexually Transmitted
            Diseases (STDs) Prevention and Management Project is
            intended to help implement the AIDS strategy presented in
            the 1994 Presidential and Ministerial decrees. These policy
            pronouncements are aimed at achieving lower STD and HIV
            incidence and fewer deaths from AIDS in Indonesia, and the
            aim of this project is to use intensive pilot efforts to
            develop institutional mechanisms and interventions capable
            of reducing transmission of STDs) and HIV in Indonesia. A
            core program for STD and HIV prevention in two pilot areas
            will be designed and implemented in partnership with local
            nongovernmental organizations (NGOs); extensive monitoring
            and evaluation will identify which trial interventions were
            promising and worth continuing. The project consists of
            provincial level components and complementary central level
            activities. Provincial (including district and
            municipality-managed) interventions will introduce
            simultaneously and in the same localities various behavior
            changes and service delivery measures thought likely to
            achieve significant outcomes. Behavioral trials and other
            interventions to reduce or prevent risk will typically be
            carried out by NGOs and will include peer and workplace
            education, counseling and other measures targeted at
            different groups.
